channel.title: Metals Industry News Feed
channel.description: Automated news feed for aluminum, steel, copper, and nickel industries

item.title: Aluminum Rises Past $3,000
item.description: Aluminum futures in the UK surpassed $3,000 per tonne for the first time since 2022 at the turn of the year, driven by growing concerns about insufficient global supply amid structural constraints in production capacity.

item.title: Move over gold and silver: Copper, aluminium head for monster rally in 2026
item.description: Aluminum prices climbed past $3,000 per tonne for the first time in over three years, lifted by structural supply constraints including China's smelting capacity caps and reduced European output due to high power costs. Strong long-term demand from construction, renewable energy, and infrastructure projects continues to support prices, with futures rising 17% in 2025.

item.title: Nickel Higher on Mine Suspension
item.description: Nickel rose 1.6% to $16,910, breaking 14-month highs following the suspension of Vale's Indonesia mine. Recent support comes from Indonesia's announcement to cut nickel ore output by a third in 2026 to support prices. This occurs amid broader base metal movements, with demand in China remaining resilient.

item.title: Vale Indonesia halts mining activities on delayed approval for 2026 output plan
item.description: PT Vale Indonesia suspended mining operations due to delays in obtaining government approval for its 2026 production plan. Indonesia's nickel smelter association FINI forecasts domestic demand will reach 340-350 million metric tons in 2026, representing an annual increase of up to 50 million tons.

item.title: Nickel notches 14-month high after Vale Indonesia halts mining
item.description: Nickel reached its highest price in more than 14 months following Vale Indonesia's suspension of mining activities. The price increase reflects market response to Indonesia's announced production cuts designed to support commodity prices.

item.title: Nickel's New Era: Rising Prices, Growing EV Demand, and Major Projects Moving Forward
item.description: The nickel market is shifting due to Indonesia's supply management, driving prices from $14,200 to $16,500 per ton since mid-December 2025, with projections up to $18,500-$20,000. Policies include shorter mining licenses, mine closures, and bans on new processing plants, countering prior surpluses. North American projects and EV demand signal stronger conditions for 2026.

item.title: COMMODITIES 2026: Mexican Aluminum Prices Poised to Rise After Atypical Year
item.description: Mexican aluminum industry sources expect 2026 to bring price increases and a more dynamic market despite ongoing Trump tariffs. Prices climbed back to $330/mt by year-end 2025, with some sources predicting premiums could surpass $400/mt.

item.title: Global Iron and Steel Prices and News 04.01.2026
item.description: SteelRadar provides daily updates on global iron and steel prices, including Shanghai Futures Rebar 3-month term and various 1-month futures for Turkey, China, Europe, and North America, all showing no change as of 02.01.2026. The platform offers analyses and comments on industry trends. This reflects stable futures pricing at the start of 2026.[6]

item.title: Fertiliser, steel prices fall; cement remains stable
item.description: Steel bar prices in Pakistan have fallen to a range of Rs220,000 to Rs230,000 per tonne from Rs240,000 to Rs250,000 per tonne as of early January 2026, due to weak demand. The Secretary General of the Pakistan Association of Large Steel Producers noted leading brands at Rs226,000 per tonne, with some as low as Rs215,000. This decline aligns with broader price reductions in fertilizers while cement prices remain stable amid rising construction demand.[4]

item.title: Vale Indonesia halts mining amid delayed 2026 output approval
item.description: PT Vale Indonesia suspended mining activities due to delays in government approval of its 2026 annual production plan (RKAB). The halt comes as Indonesia's government plans to cut nickel output quotas to support prices, with Deputy Mining Minister Yuliot Tanjung stating the approval is "currently being consolidated."

item.title: Tenaris to invest in hydrogen steelmaking in Italy
item.description: Tubemaker Tenaris has signed an agreement with Italian energy suppliers Edison and Snam for a project aimed at using hydrogen in steelmaking operations at the Tenaris Dalmine seamless tube plant in Italy. The project will study hydrogen supply and adapt the mill to use the gas in the steelmaking process, which could further lower CO2 emissions from the electric arc furnace-based steelmaker.

item.title: Tenaris Acquires isOplus Oil and Gas Division in $10M Deal
item.description: Tenaris acquired the oil and gas division of isOplus for $10 million, gaining ownership of pre-insulated pipeline systems and anti-corrosion coatings. The business unit was rebranded as Tenaris Coating Italy and will apply anti-corrosion coatings to line pipes at Tenaris facilities across Italy, Mexico, Argentina, and Brazil.

item.title: [SMM Nickel Midday Review] Nickel Prices Rise Slightly on January 5, South Korean President Lee Jae-myung Makes First Visit to China
item.description: Nickel prices rose slightly on January 5 according to the SMM midday review. The update coincides with South Korean President Lee Jae-myung's first visit to China. This reflects ongoing market movements in nickel amid regional developments.

item.title: Aluminum starts the year on a bullish note
item.description: Aluminum prices have surpassed $3,000 per ton on U.S. and European exchanges, with the Comex exchange listing aluminum at $3,050.75 per metric ton. Supply-side factors driving the price increase include declining output in China due to government-imposed smelting capacity caps and production constraints in Europe from high electricity prices, while demand from construction and renewable sectors remains robust.

item.title: PRICE INCREASE ANNOUNCEMENT - January 5, 2026
item.description: Domestic steel mills announced sharp price increases for all January 2026 orders across all markets. The hikes are driven by various market factors pressuring steel pricing.

item.title: Korea steel industry faces triple hit from structural slump, tariffs, and ...
item.description: Korea's steel industry anticipates ongoing challenges in 2026 due to structural downturns, tariff burdens, and weak demand in real estate and construction. Cumulative crude steel production from January to November 2025 was 56.1 million tons, down 3.7% year-over-year, potentially reaching the lowest in 15 years. Experts highlight a mismatch between production capacity and demand in both domestic and export markets.

item.title: Shanghai copper kicks off 2026 strong on supply jitters
item.description: Shanghai copper opened the year strongly due to intensified supply concerns from a strike at a Chilean mine. The most-active copper contract rose amid these jitters. This reflects broader market sensitivity to production disruptions.

item.title: Capstone Copper (ASX:CSC) Drops on Chile Strike
item.description: Capstone Copper's shares fell 4% to A$14.51 following a strike by workers at its Mantoverde mine in Chile starting January 2, 2026. The strike impacts operations at this key copper facility. This event highlights vulnerabilities in copper supply chains.

item.title: On January 5, the SMM #1 refined nickel price was ...
item.description: The SMM #1 refined nickel price on January 5 stood at 133700-142600 yuan/mt, with an average price of 138150 yuan/mt. This marks an increase of 600 yuan/mt from the previous day. The report highlights the latest spot pricing trends in the nickel market.

item.title: Sphere joins Nickel Industries ENC move in Indonesia
item.description: Sphere has joined Nickel Industries' ENC move in Indonesia, signaling new developments in nickel operations or investments. This activity occurs amid rising nickel prices and production adjustments in the region. Details on the specific collaboration or capacity implications remain limited in the report.

item.title: Why Alcoa (AA) Is Up 5.2% After Aluminum Tops $3,000 Amid Supply Strains And ESG Demand
item.description: Alcoa's stock rose 5.2% as LME aluminum prices exceeded $3,000 per ton due to supply constraints in China and Europe tightening inventories, alongside strong demand from construction and renewables. The company benefits from its lower-carbon aluminum production aligning with ESG trends. Upcoming Q4 2025 earnings on January 22 will reveal impacts on sales and margins.

item.title: LME aluminium surges as cash offer hits USD 3,022.5 per tonne
item.description: LME aluminum cash offer reached USD 3,022.5 per tonne on January 5, extending gains supported by lower inventories and stronger demand factors. Global supply constraints continue to bolster prices amid robust sector outlooks.

item.title: Nucor holds HR spot price at $950/ton
item.description: Nucor maintained its consumer spot price for hot-rolled coil unchanged at $950 per short ton for a third consecutive week. The steelmaker's West Coast joint venture, California Steel Industries, also kept prices steady at $1,000/st, with lead times continuing at 3 to 5 weeks.

item.title: Metal Market Update: Steel & Aluminum Prices Heading Into 2026
item.description: Sheffield Metals announced steel price increases going into Q1 2026, driven by mill maintenance downtime, the Nippon/US Steel situation, and coating extras. The video discusses how tariffs and inventory restocking are stretching lead times, with price increases expected to take effect in mid to late January.

item.title: SGH and Steel Dynamics confirm the submission of a NBIO to acquire BlueScope Steel Ltd.
item.description: SGH and Steel Dynamics submitted a Non-Binding Indicative Offer for SGH to acquire 100% of BlueScope Steel via scheme of arrangement, followed by on-selling North American operations like the North Star mill to Steel Dynamics. The firms argue BlueScope's Australia/ROW and North American businesses are not strategically compatible and would thrive separately. The proposal aligns with SGH's industrial focus and complements SDI's steel operations.

item.title: Nickel extracted from Mati City supplies global EV battery market
item.description: Hallmark Mining Corp in Mati City, Davao Oriental, Philippines, extracts nickel laterite ore shipped to China and Indonesia for EV batteries, supporting global clean energy transition. The Philippines, second-largest nickel producer, complies with environmental standards and plans mine rehabilitation. Demand for battery-grade nickel is expected to grow through 2040 amid decarbonization efforts.

item.title: AISI: Weekly raw steel mill output ticks up
item.description: US steel mills produced an estimated 1,704,000 short tons of raw steel in the week ending January 3, up 9,000 tons from the previous week, though output remains low compared to recent months. The mill capability utilization rate was 74.4%, up slightly from the prior week but down from last year. Production increased in most regions, with the South seeing a decline.

item.title: Raw material prices rise sharply at the start of 2026, lifting stainless steel futures
item.description: Key industrial metals such as copper, aluminium and nickel posted pronounced price increases in early January, with nickel up around 8% over two weeks amid talk of Indonesian output limits.[5] Stainless steel futures on the Shanghai Futures Exchange climbed nearly 2%, signaling potential upward pressure on finished stainless steel prices.[5]

item.title: Night Session SHFE Aluminum Rises Over 2%, Breaking Through 24100 yuan/mt, Multiple Positive Factors Support Aluminum Prices
item.description: SHFE aluminum 2602 contract surged 2.20% to close at 24,165 yuan/mt during the January 5 night session, driven by positive supply factors amid year-end trading. Spot prices in major Chinese regions rose 100-300 yuan/mt, though high prices suppressed downstream demand, with operating rates declining. Medium-term demand from policy support is expected, but environmental restrictions impact production.

item.title: New Heat-Resistant Alloys: In Japan, 3D Printing Pushes the Limits of Aluminum
item.description: Researchers at Nagoya University developed new aluminum alloys using metal 3D printing technology that achieve greater mechanical strength and heat tolerance, with one variant maintaining both strength and flexibility at temperatures up to 300°C. The breakthrough uses laser powder bed fusion to trap iron and other elements in metastable forms, creating alloys with copper, manganese, and titanium that are lightweight, durable, and recyclable, with promising applications in automotive and aerospace components.

item.title: Australia's BlueScope Steel mulls US$8.8 bn takeover bid | Business
item.description: Australia's BlueScope Steel is evaluating a Aus$13.2 billion (US$8.8 billion) joint takeover bid from US-based Steel Dynamics and Australian firm SGH. Under the proposal, SGH would acquire all shares and sell BlueScope's North American operations to Steel Dynamics while retaining the rest. BlueScope stated it is considering the indicative proposal against its own forecasts for improvements in costs, productivity, cashflow, and earnings.

item.title: Australia's BlueScope Steel mulls US$8.8 billion takeover bid
item.description: Australia's BlueScope Steel is assessing a joint Aus$13.2 billion takeover bid from Steel Dynamics and SGH, marking the fourth attempt by the US firm to acquire its American operations. The plan involves SGH buying all shares and on-selling North American assets to Steel Dynamics. BlueScope is weighing the offer against its internal value projections, having rejected prior bids as undervaluing the company.

item.title: BlueScope Steel Rejects US Steel Dynamics' Bids
item.description: BlueScope Steel has rejected multiple takeover bids from US-based Steel Dynamics, including all-cash, partial, and mixed proposals aimed at its US assets. The board cited concerns over valuation, execution risks, funding, and regulatory approvals despite premiums offered. The rejections underscore BlueScope's confidence in its independent strategy as Australia's leading steel manufacturer.

item.title: Copper - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
item.description: Copper rose to 6.02 USD/Lbs on January 6, 2026, up 1.82% from the previous day, with futures climbing above $5.8 per pound amid tightening global supply and concerns over potential US tariffs redirecting shipments. Over the past month, prices have risen 12.46% and are up 45.08% year-over-year. This continues a strong upward trend into the new year.

item.title: With the copper price hitting a new record, how can you get exposure?
item.description: Copper prices hit a record high amid supply disruptions at major mines like Grasberg in Indonesia, Kamoa-Kakula in Congo, and El Teniente in Chile, straining the supply chain with falling ore grades and high US stockpiles. Refined copper is forecasted to face a 600,000-tonne deficit in 2026 after a 200,000-tonne deficit in 2025. Companies like BHP boosted production to over two million tonnes in FY25, while Rio Tinto upgraded its 2025 guidance to 860,000-875,000 tonnes.

item.title: Copper Prices Soar to Record High
item.description: Copper prices reached a record $13,000 per tonne driven by mine outages, including a strike at Mantoverde in Chile, and accidents in Indonesia and Congo, alongside rising demand for energy transition applications. In 2025, prices surged 42%, the best annual gain since 2009. Potential US import tariffs have spurred shipments to the US, reducing supplies elsewhere and impacting global inventory flows.

item.title: Already up 15% in 2026, how high can this penny stock rise?
item.description: Nickel Industries Ltd (ASX: NIC), a nickel pig iron producer, has surged nearly 15% in early 2026 trading to $0.95, driven by rising nickel prices, an increased ore sales permit, and a strategic partnership. Broker Bell Potter maintains a buy rating with a $1.30 price target, citing LME nickel's recent surge from an 8-month low to a 14-month high as a key catalyst amid market volatility.

item.title: Nickel Price Forecast: Top Trends for Nickel in 2026
item.description: Analyst Manthey forecasts nickel prices to remain under pressure throughout 2026, struggling to hold above US$16,000 per ton due to ongoing market dynamics. This outlook highlights persistent challenges in the nickel market despite recent volatility.

item.title: MEMR allows limited mining output amid 2026 RKAB delays
item.description: Indonesia's Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources permits mining companies to operate at up to 25% of 2026 planned output until March 31 due to delays in RKAB approvals, amid plans to curb nickel output for price support. PT Vale Indonesia suspended mining operations without approval. The circular addresses transition issues during quota adjustments.

item.title: NALCO Shares Skyrocket to Record High as Aluminum Prices Breach $3000 Mark
item.description: NALCO shares surged 6% to a record high on January 6, driven by global aluminum prices crossing $3,000/tonne, the highest in over three years. Supply constraints in China and Europe, plus strong demand from construction and renewables, fuel the rally. The stock has risen 30% in the past month and 74% over 12 months.

item.title: On January 6, 2026, the Foshan aluminum market witnessed a stark divergence
item.description: The SMM A00 (Foshan) aluminum price jumped 610 yuan/mt on January 6, 2026, highlighting a stark divergence in the Foshan aluminum market.

item.title: NALCO Shares Skyrocket to Record High as Aluminum Prices Breach $3000 Mark
item.description: NALCO shares rose 6% to a record high on Jan. 6, 2026, driven by aluminum prices topping $3,000/tonne from China's capacity caps, European constraints, and demand in construction/renewables. The stock gained 30% in the past month despite mixed analyst targets. LME prices hit levels unseen since 2022.

item.title: SMU price ranges: Sheet and plate prices continue to rise into 2026
item.description: Steel sheet and plate prices rose across the board to start 2026 due to limited spot availability at mills, expectations of higher scrap prices, and hopes for stronger demand. Hot-rolled coil averages $930 per short ton, up $20 from prior assessment, with cold-rolled coil at $1,090 and extended lead times reported. Mills are adjusting contracts amid anticipated scrap cost increases.

item.title: Copper Extends Rally, Bursting Through $13000 a Ton - Commodities Roundup
item.description: Copper prices extended their rally, breaking through $13,000 a ton, driven by market movements in commodities. The article covers broader commodity updates but highlights the continued upward momentum in copper amid supply concerns. No specific production details are provided in the excerpt.

item.title: Melissa “Mel” Sanderson to Champion Critical Minerals Sustainability at Future Minerals Forum 2026
item.description: Melissa Sanderson, Co-Chair of the Critical Minerals Institute, will speak at FMF 2026 on sustainable critical minerals development, emphasizing ESG integration and responsible supply chains. The forum, hosted by Saudi Arabia, covers exploration, investment, and policy for minerals supporting energy transition and tech innovation. Her expertise from diplomacy and mining promotes aligning public policy with private sector for resilient ecosystems.

item.title: Nickel Prices Surge on Huge Volumes | Rebound fueled by mounting supply risks during broad metals rally
item.description: Nickel prices surged more than 10% on huge trading volumes, driven by mounting supply risks and a broad metals rally. Chinese buying fueled the spike amid concerns over supply disruptions. The rebound highlights strong speculative interest in the nickel market.

item.title: Nickel Prices Surge on Huge Volumes | Rebound fueled by mounting supply risks during broad metals rally
item.description: Nickel prices surged more than 10% on huge trading volumes, driven by Chinese buying and mounting supply risks. The rebound occurs amid a broader metals rally, with focus on potential supply constraints.

item.title: Steelmakers in US maintain steady output
item.description: US steelmakers ended 2025 with over 89.3 million tons produced through December 27, up 3.4% from 2024, and continued with 1.7 million tons in the week ending January 3, a 0.5% rise week-over-week and 1.4% higher than last year. Capacity utilization stood at 74.4%, down from 75.6% a year ago due to added EAF capacity. Steady production is pressuring recycled steel prices upward.

item.title: Viewpoint: Mexican flat steel could recover in 2026
item.description: Mexico's flat steel market anticipates recovery in 2026 after two years of contraction, supported by potential US tariffs, rising US HRC prices, and falling imports. January-November 2025 steel production fell 9% year-over-year to 15.47 million tons, while consumption dropped 10% to 23 million tons. Mills raised HRC prices twice in December amid these dynamics.

item.title: Copper surges past $13,000/t as bull run gains pace
item.description: Copper prices have surged past $13,000/t amid expectations of a 650,000–850,000t copper concentrate supply shortfall in 2026. The benchmark annual TC/RC settlement between Jiangxi Copper and Antofagasta concluded at $0/t and 0.0¢/lb, down significantly from 2025 levels, signaling tight supply risks. Market participants forecast strong copper prices in early 2026 due to insufficient mine output.

item.title: [SMM Analysis] Market Speculative Enthusiasm Soars, Overnight Multiple SHFE Nickel Contracts Hit Limit Up
item.description: Multiple SHFE nickel contracts hit limit-up during the night session on January 6, 2026, with the most-traded 2602 contract closing at 147,720 yuan/mt, while LME nickel reached $18,785/mt. Speculative funds flooded in amid concerns over global supply stability from U.S.-Venezuela relations and Indonesia's policies, pushing spot SMM #1 refined nickel to an average of 150,150 yuan/mt, up 6,700 yuan/mt. Inventories are building, but smelters are increasing production significantly.

item.title: Nickel drops from 19-month high as metals rally takes breather
item.description: Nickel futures fell 1.2% to $18,295 a ton on the LME after spiking as much as 10.5% to near $18,800 a ton on Tuesday. The drop came as the broader metals rally paused following recent sharp gains. Nickel, used in stainless steel and batteries, saw high volatility in early Shanghai trading.

item.title: LME nickel prices surpass $17000, reaching 15-month high
item.description: LME nickel futures closed at $17,003/ton on January 5, marking the highest level since October 2024 and a 15-month high. The surge reflects strong market momentum in base metals. Prices continued to climb in subsequent sessions amid broader trends.

item.title: [SMM Analysis] Market Speculative Enthusiasm Soars, Overnight Multiple SHFE Nickel Contracts Hit Limit Up
item.description: SHFE nickel contracts hit limit-up on January 6 night session, with the main 2602 contract closing at 147,720 yuan/mt amid soaring speculative enthusiasm. Smelters are ramping up production, with December output up 22% MoM and January expected to rise 18% MoM, while inventories continue to build at LME (255,000 mt) and domestic levels (59,000 mt). Focus remains on Indonesia's quota implementation amid tightening expectations versus actual surplus.

item.title: Low-Carbon Nickel Sulfate Emerges as Key Innovation in Energy & Material Technologies for Environmental Protection, Boosting New Energy Sector
item.description: Low-carbon nickel sulfate is highlighted as a pivotal innovation in energy and material technologies to enhance environmental protection. It supports the growing global demand for sustainable solutions in the new energy sector. This development boosts the transition to cleaner energy applications.

item.title: Indonesia cuts nickel mining quota to support prices, imports needed in 2026
item.description: Indonesia has reduced its nickel mining quota to bolster prices amid expectations of increased imports in 2026. This policy adjustment aims to stabilize the nickel market and support sustainable production levels. It reflects efforts to balance supply with global demand for nickel in technology applications.

item.title: Cogne Acciai Speciali launches pilot phase of green hydrogen project
item.description: Cogne Acciai Speciali, a leading Italian steel producer, has launched the pilot phase of its 'Green Hydrogen in Cogne' project at its Aosta plant. The company installed a 1.008 MW Anion Exchange Membrane electrolyzer capable of producing 165 tons of hydrogen per year, which will power one of its 70 furnaces entirely and prevent up to 26 tons of carbon emissions per ton of hydrogen. The project is supported by €7.9 million in funding from Italy's National Recovery and Resilience Plan.

item.title: Aluminum Falls Slightly After Hitting 3-Year High, But Remains Up Over 23% Year-on-Year
item.description: Aluminum prices eased to about $3,087–3,086 per tonne on January 7, 2026, down roughly 1.5% from the previous day after recently breaking above $3,100, the highest level in over three years.[1] Despite the pullback, prices are up around 6.8% over the past month and more than 23% compared with the same time last year, supported by tighter supply as China reiterates its cap on aluminum smelting capacity.[1]

item.title: NALCO Shares Skyrocket to Record High as Aluminum Prices Breach $3,000 Mark
item.description: National Aluminum Company Ltd. (NALCO) shares jumped as much as 6% to a record high, driven by global aluminum prices crossing $3,000 per tonne, a level not seen in more than three years.[4] The rally is being fueled by supply constraints in China and Europe and strong demand from construction and renewable energy sectors, even as analysts caution that the stock’s current valuation may already price in much of the optimism.[4]

item.title: Aluminium Price Spikes Driven by Global Supply Concerns in 2026
item.description: London Metal Exchange aluminium futures recently climbed to about $3,008 per tonne in early 2026, breaching the $3,000 mark for the first time since mid‑2022.[6] The move is attributed to global supply concerns, including constrained capacity in key producing regions, which are tightening the market and supporting higher prices.[6]

item.title: Vedanta Aluminium scales Lanjigarh refinery and sets alumina production record
item.description: Vedanta Aluminium has announced a new production record at its Lanjigarh alumina refinery, highlighting a significant scale-up in alumina output.[2] The achievement underpins Vedanta’s strategy to secure raw material supply for its aluminium smelting operations and strengthen its position in the global aluminium value chain.[2]

item.title: RPM Announces Acquisition of Kalzip
item.description: RPM International has acquired Kalzip, a globally recognized leader in aluminum roofing and façade systems headquartered in Germany. The acquisition enhances the company's position in aluminum building envelope technologies and creates opportunities to expand these systems to North American customers.

item.title: Paragon Union, Japan's Asahi Seiren Form JV To Tap US$160 Billion Recycled Aluminum Market
item.description: A joint venture between Paragon Union and Japan's Asahi Seiren has been formed to tap into the US$160 billion recycled aluminum market, reflecting growing industry focus on circular economy solutions and sustainable aluminum production.

item.title: HRC steel prices edge higher, extending strong year-on-year gains
item.description: US hot-rolled coil (HRC) steel prices rose to about 937 USD/ton, up roughly 0.8% on the day and more than 33% higher than a year ago.[2] Analysts expect HRC to remain firm, with forecasts pointing toward prices near 960 USD/ton by quarter‑end and above 1,030 USD/ton in 12 months.[2]

item.title: North EU HRC futures continue to firm despite quiet spot market
item.description: CME North European hot‑rolled coil futures moved higher, with second‑quarter strips trading around €676/ton as derivatives participants reported solid buying interest.[4] The strength in futures contrasts with a relatively subdued physical market but reflects expectations of tighter supply and steady demand into Q2.[4]

item.title: Stainless steel coil prices rise in China on stronger nickel and sentiment
item.description: Prices for 304 2.0mm cold‑rolled stainless steel coil in China increased to about 13,400–13,500 yuan/ton in early January, up from roughly 12,800–12,900 yuan/ton in mid‑December 2025.[4] The gains track a sharp rally in nickel and improved macro sentiment, which are lifting stainless steel production costs and spot offers.[4]

item.title: Tata Steel Q3FY26 update: Crude steel production rises 11.4% YoY; Europe lags
item.description: Tata Steel India’s crude steel production increased **11.4% year-on-year to 6.34 million tonnes** in Q3FY26, with delivery volumes up 14% to 6.04 million tonnes, reflecting strong domestic demand.[2] In contrast, Tata Steel Netherlands saw a 4.5% decline in production to 1.68 million tonnes and an 8.5% fall in sales, while Tata Steel UK’s production was nil as both blast furnaces have ceased operations, leading to a 9% drop in delivery volumes to 0.52 million tonnes.[2]

item.title: International GalvaNext-2026 conference to begin in Jamshedpur on ‘Next Generation Galvanized and Color Coatings’
item.description: An international GalvaNext‑2026 conference on next-generation galvanized and color coatings is being held in Jamshedpur, bringing together experts, researchers, and industry professionals from India and abroad to discuss hot‑dip coatings and advanced steel surface technologies.[5] The two‑day event emphasizes sustainability, emerging coating technologies, and future‑ready solutions for the galvanized and color‑coated steel industry, with over 70 technical papers and dedicated panels on technological innovation and long‑term strategic direction.[5]

item.title: Comex Copper Settles 3.35% Lower at $5.8090 — Data Talk
item.description: Front-month Comex copper for January delivery fell 3.35% to $5.8090 per pound, snapping a three-session winning streak and marking its largest one-day percentage decline since late December 2025.[3] Despite the pullback, prices remain near historic levels, logging the third-highest close on record and standing more than 37% above year-ago levels.[3]

item.title: Copper – Price, Chart, Historical Data and News
item.description: Copper prices slipped to about $5.93 per pound on 7 January, down 1.45% from the prior day after hitting fresh record highs near $6.06 earlier in the month.[1] Even with the latest pullback, copper remains up roughly 40% year‑on‑year, supported by tight supply expectations and strong investor interest.[1]

item.title: Bernstein issues new copper prices target for 2026
item.description: Bernstein forecasts copper will average $11,500 per tonne in Q1 2026 before moderating to around $10,000 per tonne in the second half as market momentum fades.[2] The firm attributes today’s all‑time‑high prices above $13,000 per tonne to a mix of natural supply disruptions, labor issues, and speculative activity tied to the electrification theme, but warns that weaker EV demand and negative macro headlines could trigger sharp corrections.[2]

item.title: Copper prices near all-time high: Structural shift or speculative spike?
item.description: MCX January 2026 copper futures climbed over 1.3% to around Rs 1,330 per kg, bringing domestic prices close to lifetime highs amid the global rally.[5] The article discusses whether the surge reflects a long‑term structural shift driven by energy transition demand or a shorter‑term speculative spike vulnerable to correction.[5]

item.title: Rewiring Sustainable, Clean Energy Future With Copper
item.description: This article explains how copper’s high electrical and thermal conductivity, combined with its 100% recyclability, make it a critical enabler of the clean energy transition and circular economy. It highlights forecasts that copper demand for clean energy could nearly double by 2050, emphasizes that almost one‑third of global copper demand is already met through recycling, and describes mining-sector innovations to cut water and energy use while improving environmental performance.[1]

item.title: The Trends Shaping the Data Center in 2026 and Beyond
item.description: Siemon outlines how evolving copper cabling technologies are supporting higher‑speed data center interconnects while helping operators meet tightening sustainability requirements.[5] The article details advances such as active copper cable assemblies and new mesh constructions that improve energy efficiency, thermal management, and material use, positioning copper as a key element of more sustainable AI and cloud data centers.[5]

item.title: Copper, nickel retreat from highs as rally loses steam
item.description: Nickel prices on the LME fell about 2.3% to roughly $18,085 per tonne after earlier touching around $18,800, as the recent rally lost momentum amid profit‑taking.[6] Traders cited overextended positioning and questions about the sustainability of recent gains despite earlier strength driven by supply concerns and macro optimism.[6]

item.title: Nickel prices remain high despite copper nearing record levels
item.description: Nickel prices hit a 19‑month high after the Indonesian government cut mining quotas for 2026, sending Shanghai nickel up about 7.3% to roughly 146,770 yuan/ton and briefly to its highest level since June 2024.[3] LME nickel also reached around $18,785 per tonne before easing, with analysts warning that weak fundamentals could make the market vulnerable to short‑term profit‑taking.[3]

item.title: Asian Nickel Prices Continue to Rise Sharply
item.description: Asian nickel prices jumped by up to about 8% in the latest session, extending gains of more than 25% on the SHFE since early December 2025, driven by Indonesia’s plan to restrict nickel ore mining.[4] The sharp rise is feeding through into higher stainless steel spot prices in Asia and raising cost concerns for downstream industries.[4]

item.title: Nickel Prices Soar Over 10%, But Analysts Warn Rally Is Unsustainable
item.description: Nickel prices have surged by more than 10% recently on supply fears and Indonesian policy moves, but several banks argue the rally overshoots long‑term fundamentals.[5] ING and the World Bank both project average nickel prices around $15,250–$15,500 per tonne in 2026, implying downside risk from current elevated spot levels.[5]

item.title: Nickel prices hit 15‑month high on robust sentiment
item.description: Nickel climbed to a 15‑month high as bullish sentiment around Indonesian output restrictions and strong stainless steel demand outweighed concerns about ample supply.[8] Argus notes that despite the current spike, the average nickel price in 2025 was $15,349/t, down from $17,049/t in 2024, underscoring how recent gains contrast with prior price softness.[8]

item.title: Nickel prices jump after top producer Indonesia signals 2026 output cut
item.description: Nickel prices rose to their highest level since March after Indonesia, which now accounts for over 60% of global nickel supply, announced plans to cut production in 2026 to balance the market.[2] Spot nickel climbed to about $16,500 per tonne from $15,800, while the three‑month LME contract rallied 6.4% as investors anticipated tighter supply and improved pricing power.[2]

item.title: Pressure for Indonesian quota U-turn is a risk for nickel price rally
item.description: Indonesia, which accounts for about 70% of global nickel production, has cut mining quotas, helping drive nickel prices to around 19‑month highs near $18,800/ton and more than 30% above recent levels.[3] Analysts warn that political and industry pressure for a reversal of these restrictions could unleash additional supply later in the year as new projects ramp up and quotas are potentially relaxed, tempering the rally.[3]

item.title: Nickel still capped by surplus
item.description: ING analysts forecast that the **global nickel market will remain in surplus through 2026**, with supply growth—driven largely by Indonesia—continuing to outpace demand.[1] The article notes that environmental scrutiny of Indonesia’s HPAL (high-pressure acid leach) projects and evolving EV battery chemistries, including a shift toward lower‑nickel LFP batteries, are reshaping the technology and sustainability landscape for nickel used in clean energy applications.[1]

item.title: Indonesian Nickel Quota U-Turn Pressure Drives Price Rally
item.description: Discovery Alert reports that expectations of a **policy reversal on Indonesia’s nickel output quotas** have triggered a price rally in nickel markets.[4] The piece highlights how changing quota and infrastructure investment policies in Indonesia, a dominant producer for EV and battery supply chains, could influence future project economics, technology deployment, and the sustainability profile of nickel-intensive industries.[4]

item.title: Cavi in rame, Antitrust avvia indagine su presunto cartello: Prysmian e Nexans in calo in Borsa
item.description: L’Autorità Antitrust italiana (AGCM) ha avviato un’indagine su un presunto cartello tra alcuni dei principali produttori di cavi in rame a bassa tensione in Italia, tra cui Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia, ipotizzando un coordinamento sui prezzi a partire dal 2005.[1] Sono state effettuate ispezioni presso le sedi delle società coinvolte e di alcuni distributori; in Borsa il titolo Prysmian ha registrato un calo, anche se vari analisti stimano un impatto economico limitato perché il mercato italiano dei cavi in rame a bassa tensione pesa per meno del 3% sui ricavi del gruppo.[1]

item.title: Prysmian shares rise as Italian cable maker seen as winner amid US copper tariffs
item.description: Le azioni Prysmian sono salite fino al 4% sulla Borsa di Milano dopo l’annuncio di nuovi dazi statunitensi sull’import di rame, con il gruppo visto dagli analisti come uno dei principali beneficiari grazie alla sua integrazione verticale e fornitura domestica di rame negli USA.[2] Gli esperti ritengono che Prysmian, grande acquirente globale di rame con un’importante presenza nel mercato americano, possa trasferire i maggiori costi ai clienti e rafforzare i margini nel business dei cavi a bassa tensione negli Stati Uniti.[2]

item.title: National Aluminium Share Price Today, January 8
item.description: National Aluminium Co Ltd shares were trading down about 3.9% in early trade on January 8 after a strong run to fresh record highs in recent sessions, which had been underpinned by rising global aluminum prices and positive industry fundamentals.[5] The stock remains significantly higher over the past year, reflecting improved profitability and sentiment tied to the global aluminum price uptrend.[5]

item.title: Commodity Radar: Bauxite helps to hold the capesize market
item.description: China is keeping its primary aluminium production capped at 45 million tonnes per year, with output for the first 11 months of 2025 reported at 41.4 million tonnes, implying limited December production capacity to stay within the cap.[5] The article notes that this cap supports continued strong bauxite and alumina demand, and that growing aluminium smelting capacity in countries such as Indonesia could drive higher alumina exports from China and alter future bauxite trade flows.[5]

item.title: CES 2026: Reviewed announces its awards for tech's best products
item.description: Features innovative aluminum alloy technology in consumer products, including a trademarked aluminum alloy that is significantly stronger than standard 6061 aluminum and outperforms TA2 titanium in key strength metrics. The material engineering provides exceptional resistance to dents, scratches, and long-term wear without adding bulk.

item.title: Steel falls as China growth worries cap recent gains
item.description: Benchmark Chinese steel prices slipped to about 3,146 CNY/ton, down around 0.4% from the previous day, even though they remain roughly 3% higher over the past month.[1] The market has been supported by expectations of fresh Chinese policy easing, but lingering concerns about construction demand and the broader economy are limiting further upside.[1]

item.title: Tata Steel India posts best-ever quarterly crude steel output in Q3FY26
item.description: In its Q3 update, Tata Steel India reported its **best-ever quarterly crude steel production** at 6.34 million tonnes, up about 12% quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year, driven by higher output at its Jamshedpur and Kalinganagar plants.[1] The update also notes that Tata Steel Netherlands produced 1.68 million tonnes of liquid steel with deliveries of 1.40 million tonnes in Q3FY26.[1]

item.title: Budget 2027: Assocham seeks incentives for hydrogen-based green steel production
item.description: Industry body Assocham has urged the Indian government to offer incentives for **hydrogen-based direct reduced iron (DRI)** and concessional green finance to support the steel sector’s transition to low-carbon production in the FY27 Budget.[3] The group highlights that despite India’s 8–9% steel growth and position as the world’s second-largest producer, high input costs, dependence on imported coking coal, stagnant iron ore production, and pressure on raw material supply are constraining capacity and raising costs.[3]

item.title: Union Budget: Assocham seeks incentives for hydrogen steel, green finance
item.description: Ahead of India’s Union Budget, Assocham has called for policy support including incentives for **hydrogen-based steelmaking**, concessional green finance, and stronger backing for recycling and R&D to help expand low-carbon steel capacity.[6] The chamber warns that elevated raw material costs, a weak rupee, and near-total reliance on imported coking coal are squeezing margins and could hinder future capacity additions without supportive measures.[6]

item.title: Gov't discusses response to EU's carbon tax policy with steel industry
item.description: South Korea’s Ministry of Trade, Industry and Resources met with major domestic steelmakers to discuss responses to the EU’s **Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM)**, which began applying to carbon-intensive imports such as steel on January 1.[4] Steel producers said they have prepared compliance measures, including securing EU-recognized carbon verification, but requested continued government efforts to reduce uncertainties around the evolving policy, which could affect export competitiveness and future investment decisions.[4]

item.title: Europe's steel industry faces its 2026 reckoning with CBAM
item.description: From January 2026, the EU’s **Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism** begins to materially impact Europe’s steelmakers, marking a turning point where climate policy starts to reshape steel sector balance sheets.[5] The article explains how CBAM aims to protect EU producers from carbon leakage by imposing a carbon cost on imported steel, which could influence capacity utilization, investment in low-carbon technologies, and the competitive landscape between domestic and foreign producers.[5]

item.title: The price of copper is expected to reach a historic high of $13,000 per tonne in 2026
item.description: The article discusses expectations that copper prices could climb to about $13,000 per tonne in 2026, driven largely by structural supply constraints and accelerating demand from energy transition technologies.[4] It reviews current mine output, projected production growth, and the risk that new capacity additions will not be sufficient to close the anticipated supply gap in refined copper.[4]

item.title: A Canary in an Urban Mine: Environmental and Economic Impacts of Urban Mining
item.description: CSIS analyzes how ‘urban mining’—recovering metals such as copper and gold from e‑waste—can be as cost‑efficient as traditional mining in China while offering a smaller environmental footprint.[4] The piece discusses how scaling recycling and urban mining could ease supply constraints for critical materials used in clean energy and high‑tech applications, reduce dependence on primary mining, and support more sustainable industrial systems.[4]

item.title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel Prices Retreat from Highs on January 8 as Market Sentiment Shifts from Frenzy to Caution
item.description: Nickel prices on the SHFE pulled back after a sharp rally, with the most-traded 2602 contract closing down about 2.3% around 142,020 yuan/mt, as sentiment turned from aggressive buying to more cautious profit‑taking.[1] Spot #1 refined nickel averaged 149,050 yuan/mt, down 1,100 yuan/mt day‑on‑day, while a sharp one‑day increase of 20,000 mt in LME inventories to 270,000 mt raised concerns about oversupply and near‑term volatility.[1]

item.title: Nickel prices surge on Indonesian curbs, but policy U-turn risk looms
item.description: Indonesia’s decision to cut nickel mining quotas has sharply boosted global nickel prices, underscoring the country’s dominant role in supply.[5] However, the report notes that pressure is building for a potential policy reversal, which could eventually increase mining permits and production capacity, easing the current tightness in the market.[3][5]

item.title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel prices retreat from highs on January 8 as market sentiment shifts from frenzy to caution
item.description: Nickel prices on the SHFE pulled back on January 8 after a strong rally, with spot refined nickel in China quoted at 143,400–154,700 yuan/mt and average prices down 1,100 yuan/mt from the previous trading day.[1] The review highlights a sharp one‑day increase of 20,000 mt in LME nickel inventories to 270,000 mt and notes that traders are closely watching Indonesia’s nickel policy and future production capacity as key drivers of volatility.[1]

item.title: The first Energy Release contract in the Aosta Valley is underway: agreement signed between the CVA Group and Cogne Acciai Speciali
item.description: CVA will construct four new photovoltaic plants in Sicily with a total capacity of over 20 MW, expected to produce 593,600 MWh annually and be fully operational by 2026. This marks the first Energy Release agreement in the Aosta Valley and supports Cogne Acciai Speciali's green energy transition and reduced environmental impact of production.
